title: ChannelConsumerAction.ReportAndCrash
content:
ChannelConsumerAction.ReportAndCrash ReportAndCrash

The error which should never happen. This implies a bug so we must do something on this Library For the sake of saving funds, the API consumer might attempt a channel close. But they cannot be sure that closing will always succeed.

title: ChannelConsumerAction.Close
content:
ChannelConsumerAction.Close Close

Close channel immediately. The most popular action. Might be good to lower the trust score of the peer.

title: ChannelConsumerAction.DistrustPeer
content:
ChannelConsumerAction.DistrustPeer DistrustPeer

Same with the Close in the sense that the peer did something unacceptable to us. But the channel is not open yet.

title: ChannelConsumerAction.Ignore
content:
ChannelConsumerAction.Ignore Ignore

The error is not critical to the channel operation. But it maybe good to report the log message, or maybe lower the peer score.

The functions in this module may fail but it does not return Result and just throw Exception in case of failure. Why? because the error case is very, very unlikely to happen. It is interesting to consider if it is possible for the attacker to intentionally make this happen, but it is way beyond my skills, so we just ignore for now.

title: ISecp256k1
content:
ISecp256k1

An interface responsible for set of low-level cryptographic operation. We need this because there are several types of secp256k1 implementation 1. NBitcoinSecp256k1 The one we usually want to use. Which depends on NBitcoin's implementation 2. BouncySecp256k1 Fallback when we are compiling with netstandard2.0, since NBitcoin.Secp256k1 does not support older netstandard version. * This will be obsolete when we drop the support for netstandard2.1

title: ISatisfier
content:
ISatisfier

When we verify a macaroon for its caveats, usually it check each caveats independently. In case of LSAT, this does not work since the validity of a caveat depends on a previous caveat (more specifically, if there were two caveats with a same Condition, we usually check that whether the restriction does not get more loose than before.) So we can not just rely on Macaroon's . The additional check is done with this ISatisfier Interface

ISatisfier.SatisfyFinal SatisfyFinal ISatisfier.SatisfyPrevious SatisfyPrevious ISatisfier.Condition Condition

title: ISatisfier.SatisfyFinal
content:
ISatisfier.SatisfyFinal SatisfyFinal

Satisfies the final caveat of an LSAT. If multiple caveats with the same condition exist, this will only be executed once all previous caveats are also satisfied.

title: ISatisfier.SatisfyPrevious
content:
ISatisfier.SatisfyPrevious SatisfyPrevious

ensures a caveat is in accordance with a previous one with the same condition. This is needed since caveats of the same condition can be used multiple times as long as they enforce more permissions than the previous.

For example, we have a caveat that only allows us to use an LSAT for 7 more days. we can add another caveat that only allows for 3 more days of use and lend it to another party.

title: ISatisfier.Condition
content:
ISatisfier.Condition Condition

This is the left side of caveat equation. e.g. for caveat "service=myawesomeservice", it is "service"

title: DirectedLNGraph.MakeGraph
content:
DirectedLNGraph.MakeGraph MakeGraph

This is the recommended way of creating the network graph. We don't include private channels: they would bloat the graph without providing any value(if they are private they probably don't want to be involved in routing other people's payments). The only private channels we know are ours: we should check them to see if our destination can be reached in a single hop via private channel before using the public network graph

title: FeeRatePerKw.MismatchRatio
content:
FeeRatePerKw.MismatchRatio MismatchRatio

Suppose remote = 3.0 and local = 1.0. This formula will calculate the mismatch "ratio" to be: abs (2.0 (remote - local) / (remote + local)) == abs (2.0 (3.0 - 1.0) / (3.0 + 1.0)) == abs (2.0 2.0 / 4.0) == 1.0 If remote instead equals 0.33 we get the same mismatch ratio: abs (2.0 (remote - local) / (remote + local)) == abs (2.0 (0.33 - 1.0) / (0.33 + 1.0)) == abs (2.0 0.66 / 1.33) == 1.0 This example demonstrates how the formula is both symmetrical and invariant in the scale of the parameters. ie. swapping remote and local, or scaling them both by a constant factor, will produce the same mismatch ratio. See this wikipedia entry for more info on ways of calculating relative differences: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Relative_change_and_difference

title: SeqParserCE
content:
SeqParserCE

A SeqParser is a parser for sequences. It wraps a function which takes a sequence and optionally returns a value successfully-parsed from the start of the sequence along with the rest of the sequence. If parsing fails it returns None.

You can construct a SeqParser using the seqParser computation expression. The bind operation of the computation expression will return the value parsed from the sequence and advance the sequence to the position where the next value can be parsed from. For example, given a parser parseValue, you can construct a parser which parses three values like this:

1: 
2: 
3: 
4: 
5: 
6: 

seqParser {
   let! value0 = parseValue()
   let! value1 = parseValue()
   let! value2 = parseValue()
   return (value0, value1, value2)
}

You can also call SeqParser.next and SeqParser.abort from within a seqParser to pop the next element of the sequence or to abort parsing respectively.

The function SeqParser.parseToCompletion takes a sequence and a SeqParser and will attempt to parse the sequence to completion.

SeqParserCE.SeqParser<'SeqElement, 'Value> SeqParser<'SeqElement, 'Value> SeqParserCE.SeqParserBuilder<'SeqElement> SeqParserBuilder<'SeqElement> SeqParserCE.seqParser seqParser

The remote node sets a limit on the maximum value of pending HTLCs to them at any given time to limit their funds exposure to HTLCs. This allows you to set a minimum such value.

title: ChannelHandshakeLimits.MaxChannelReserveSatoshis
content:
ChannelHandshakeLimits.MaxChannelReserveSatoshis MaxChannelReserveSatoshis

The remote node will require we keep a certain amount in direct payment to ourselves at all time, ensuring that we are able to be punished if we broadcast an old state. This allows to you limit the amount which we will have to keep to ourselves (and cannot use for HTLCs).

title: ChannelHandshakeLimits.MinMaxAcceptedHTLCs
content:
ChannelHandshakeLimits.MinMaxAcceptedHTLCs MinMaxAcceptedHTLCs

The remote node sets a limit on the maximum number of pending HTLCs to them at any given time. This allows you to set a minimum such value.

title: ChannelHandshakeLimits.MinDustLimitSatoshis
content:
ChannelHandshakeLimits.MinDustLimitSatoshis MinDustLimitSatoshis

HTLCs below this amount plus HTLC transaction fees are not enforceable on-chain. This settings allows you to set a minimum dust limit for their commitment TXs, Defaults to 546 , or the current dust limit on the Bitcoin network.

title: ChannelHandshakeLimits.MaxDustLimitSatoshis
content:
ChannelHandshakeLimits.MaxDustLimitSatoshis MaxDustLimitSatoshis

Maximum allowed threshold above which outputs will not be generated in their commitment Transactions. HTLCs below this amount plus HTLC tx fees are not enforceable on-chain.

title: ChannelHandshakeLimits.MaxMinimumDepth
content:
ChannelHandshakeLimits.MaxMinimumDepth MaxMinimumDepth

before a channel is usable the funding TX will need to be confirmed by at least a certain number of blocks, specified by the node which is not the funder (as the funder can assume they aren't going to double-spend themselves). This config allows you to set a limit on the maximum amount of time to wait. Defaults to 144 blocks or roughly one day and only applies to outbound channels.

title: ChannelHandshakeLimits.ForceChannelAnnouncementPreference
content:
ChannelHandshakeLimits.ForceChannelAnnouncementPreference ForceChannelAnnouncementPreference

Set to force the incoming channel to match our announced channel preference in ChannelConfig. Defaults to true to make the default that no announced channels are possible (which is appropriate for any nodes which are not online very reliably)

title: Heap<'T>
content:
Heap<'T>

Heap is an ordered linear structure where the ordering is ascending or descending. "head" inspects the first element in the ordering, "tail" takes the remaining structure after head, and "insert" places elements within the ordering. PriorityQueue is available as an alternate interface. According to Okasaki the time complexity of the heap functions in this Heap implementation (based on the "pairing" heap) have resisted time complexity analysis.

title: UInt48
content:
UInt48

Integral type to represent the commitment number. The commitment number is a number set to commitment tx locktime (in obscured form), see bolt03-transactions for more detail.
